keyTakeAways: Sean Grayson, a 31-year-old Illinois sheriff’s deputy, is on trial for first-degree murder, aggravated battery with a firearm, and official misconduct after shooting Sonya Massey in her Springfield home on July 6, 2024.

Massey, a 36-year-old Black woman and single mother, was shot after an incident involving a pan of hot water, during which she reportedly said 'I rebuke you in the name of Jesus,' leading Grayson to interpret it as a threat.
Body camera footage shows Grayson entered the house, ordered the removal of a hot pan, and after Massey picked it up again, fired three times, hitting her once below the left eye.
Massey had a history of mental health struggles, including recent admission to a 30-day inpatient program and multiple 911 calls from her and her mother citing mental breakdowns.
Grayson was unaware of Massey’s mental health history and had a controversial past, including a prior DUI conviction and Army discharge for drunken driving with a weapon.
Prior to the shooting, Grayson had held four policing jobs in six years, with past evaluations noting poor report writing, disorganization, and behavioral issues.
Sangamon County Sheriff Jack Campbell retired six weeks after the incident, despite having certified Grayson for employment and requiring him to attend police academy training.

In response to public outcry, Illinois Governor JB Pritzker signed legislation in August 2024 requiring full disclosure of personal and employment background records for all law enforcement candidates.
The trial was moved from Springfield to Peoria due to national attention and security concerns, with a security presence including tactical teams and snipers.

Jury selection began with questions focused on jurors’ relationships with law enforcement, their support, and whether they would find it acceptable for officers to use force as needed—no one said yes.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Sean Grayson, a Sangamon County sheriff’s deputy, is on trial for the murder of Sonya Massey, a Black woman who was shot in her Springfield home on July 6, 2024, after a confrontation over a pan of hot water. Body camera footage shows Grayson entering the home, responding to a call about a suspected prowler, and firing three times after she picked up the pan. Massey, a single mother with a history of mental health issues, had previously been admitted to a mental health program and made multiple 911 calls reporting a mental breakdown. Grayson, who had a prior DUI conviction and a history of poor performance in past policing roles, was unaware of her mental health history. The incident sparked national outrage, prompting Illinois Governor JB Pritzker to sign legislation requiring full background transparency for all law enforcement candidates. The trial was moved from Springfield to Peoria for security reasons, and jury selection began with intense questioning about attitudes toward police use of force—no juror said they believed officers could use any level of force as necessary. The case has become a focal point for discussions on racial bias, law enforcement accountability, and mental health in policing.
